comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: I'm pretty sure this man's name is "Riccio."  There are a few NY Times references to at least one Italian cabinet minister referred to by this name (which I think just means "Mr. Riccio").  Don't know why he was notable in late 1914.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Following up on rjones0856's post, Vincenzo Riccio (1858-1927) was a cabinet minister in several Italian governments of the era, including in the period between March, 1914 and June, 1916. This picture does not particulary resemble the one on this Italian history site, but Riccio was 56 in 1914, which looks appropriate for this Bain photo: cinquantamila.corriere.it/storyTellerPadrone.php?nome=Vin... Biographical sketch autotranslated from above site: "Naples, 1858, -Rome, 1928. Lawyer, journalist, contributor to magazines and periodicals, follower of Salandra, was elected in 1897 in the ranks of the Liberal Democrats; Undersecretary of the Interior (1909-1910) with Sonnino, was Minister of Posts (1914-1916) in the two Salandra cabinets, Agriculture (1919) with Orlando, succeeding resigning Miliani, and Public Works (1922) in the two Facta cabinets . [Figure 1988]" it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincenzo_Riccio_(politico)

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks for the information artolog. I think that we can safely make the change to the spelling of the name the next time we update the record. He could be the cabinet minister/author you note, but we'll hold out for a little more information to confirm.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Actually, I think this is the Italian Premier, Vittorio Orlando: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ggb2006003793/ Several other web sources identify this photo as Orlando: www.google.com/search?q=vittorio+orlando&hl=en&rl...

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content:
I agree with you, artolog:  same haircut, mustache, and bags under his eyes.  Certainly Signor Orlando would have been in all the papers back then.  

Nice catch.
